title: 107_hr1098
content:
The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" includes provisions such as the naming of vessels, expansion of the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor, discharge of agricultural cargo residue, recording and discharging maritime liens, and various certificates of documentation for vessels. The Congress recognizes the significant contributions of the United States Merchant Marine in various wars, including serving as the Nation's first navy, keeping the lifeline of freedom open during World War II, and facing dangers from enemies. Over 250,000 men and women served in the Merchant Marine during World War II. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine faced dangers from submarines, mines, armed raiders, and more. Over 6,800 members were killed at sea, 11,000 were wounded, and 604 were taken prisoner. 1 in 32 members died in the line of duty, the highest percentage among all U.S. armed services. The Merchant Marine continues to serve the U.S. and uphold the ideals of its former members. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds for additions to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants to the American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial Committee, Inc., to build an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California. The Federal government will cover 50% of the costs, with an authorization of $500,000 for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue material from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to allow for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. The Secretary must record a notice complying with the section if a declaration is filed with the notice stating the information is true and correct. The amendment allows for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. A notice must be sent to the vessel owner, holders of unexpired liens, and mortgagees. A declaration must be signed by authorized individuals. Upon full discharge of the indebtedness, a certificate of discharge must be provided to the Secretary for recording. The person with a claim must provide the Secretary an acknowledged certificate of discharge of the indebtedness, which will be recorded. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions regarding vessel liens, regardless of the amount or parties' citizenship. A notice of claim of lien expires after 3 years. This section does not change existing laws. The section expires 3 years after the specified date in the notice. It does not change laws related to maritime liens, remedies, or defenses. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to include notice requirements for liens on vessels. The Secretary cannot refuse to approve surrender of documentation based solely on a recorded lien notice. Technical corrections are made to the Shipping Act, 1916. The effective date for the amendment to section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is July 1, 2002. The Secretary of Transportation will determine the tonnage measurement for the small passenger vessel R/V DAVIDSON for regulatory purposes. This measurement applies when the vessel complies with specific requirements. Additionally, there are provisions for miscellaneous certificates of documentation. The Secretary of Transportation may issue certificates of documentation for vessels like LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, and SKIMMER. The vessels listed with their official registration numbers are: ANTJA (FL3475MA), SKIMMER (QHG34031D001), TOKEENA (SC 1602 BJ), DOUBLE EAGLE2 (1042549), ENCOUNTER (998174), AJ (599164), BARGE 10 (1101368), NOT A SHOT (911064), PRIDE OF MANY (811529), AMAZING GRACE (92769), and SHEWHO (1104094). SEC. 9. EXEMPTION FOR VICTORY SHIPS. Amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, US Code to exempt SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR 3 BARGES. SEC. 10. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for three barges for coastwise trade. The vessels are the former Navy deck barge JIM, the former railroad car barge HUGH, and the former railroad car barge TOMMY. These vessels can only be used as floating platforms for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State entity, operated for specific purposes, and clearly identified as such. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE.

Starting April 1, 2002, 10 sailboats in the New World Challenge Race can carry non-paying guests from San Francisco and San Diego ports. This provision ends either 60 days after the race's end in San Francisco or on December 31, 2003.

SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER.

The vessel ASPHALT COMMANDER (official number 663105) can be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen despite any existing agreements with the US Government.
